reviewText:
The good:

-The art direction and diverse cast of characters
-Photojournalism is the main weapon of your protagonist, and seeing it used as a concept in a fantasy setting is really refreshing
-The protagonists. Without spoiling anything, Jade and Pey'j are a memorable duo, heartwarming characters in general, and there's still plenty of mystery surrounding them. Jade and Double H were a fun team as well, and there seems to be a lot of untold depth to even the minor characters, namely anyone found in the Akuda Bar
-The soundtrack

The bad:

-The camera is sometimes wonky, especially on the PC
-It's kind of an extension of the camera problem, but controlling the game's two vehicles can be frustrating in some parts
-A little short, could have been one level/mission longer imo, but that's because I really enjoyed what I got

The ugly:

-The fact that this game was a commercial failure, isn't well known even to this day, and its sequel has been in development hell but is well deserving of existing already

Conclusion: Play this game. It's charming, unique, and refreshing despite being over a decade old.

reviewText:
Hands down one of the best Action-Adventure game ive played to this date, I loved the charecters and story and this review will tell you why I personally enjoyed each aspect of the game. (Ubisoft release BGaE 2 Please!) Before you question that I don't have the hours played on this game I have played the ps2 version and the HD remastered verson on the Xbox 360 and completed it on each platform.

What does the game offer in terms of what genre it is
The game is an Action/Adventure game with elements of Stealth and puzzle solving. The game doesnt throw you into battles all the time and most battles you can avoid by running away. The stealth in this game is almost completely optional unless theres a drone in the room, this drone only targets intruders when spotted and will instantly kill you which enforces you to be stealthy. There are puzzles to solve and most of them are easy to do like for example you have to redirect light beams to go to a certain area to access the next area.

Story
Warning: This story is not set on the planet Earth, its a factional planet called Hillys

When i first started playing I didn't know what to expect when i first played but the story grabbed me about how the population was threatened by aliens called the Domz and how they attack every so often. When you first get to play you are thrown into combat stright away and the game doesn't hold your hand when it comes to showing combat, it shows a small text at the bottom showing what you press to attack but thats it, the enemy won't wait. As you play through the game you realise that the so called protectors are your enemy and the rebel organisation is actually the good guys. There is 3 dungon like places you go into to sneak around gathering infomation about what they are actually doing and exposeing them for what they do. I could go into more detail about the story but I don't want to spoil the story

Music
EDIT: I almost forgot about the music, ill tag it here
The music in the game is one of the best composed soundtrack. Each track suits the time it is played, an example when the main character gets depressed and the soundtrack suits it as they use viloin as well as low notes to express the feelings. There are other times but its worth to play a demo of this game or to play the game to get the full feeling for the game.

Charecters
There is One main character that you control called Jade, she is the reporter and also an animal documenter (as thats a main way of obtaining units which is the currency of the game) and she looks after the orphans of Hillys and she has to leave them to do her missions which sets up the plot of the game. She has two companions throughout the game.

The first one, Pey'j is her uncle who helps looking after the orphans and is also a mechanic. He doesnt stay for long as he is captured at the factory when you are finding out about what the alpha sections are doing. Pey'j has a special ability which allows him to slam onto the ground which throws up enemys to allow you to attack them and use them as projectiles. After the main plot is developed Pey'j gets a field ability where he can cut through metal fences which allows you to access areas or to get further through the main story.

When you save Double H at the factory he joins you as the other companion throughout the rest of the game and he helps you through the remainder of the game.  Double H has a specal abilty where he uses his hammer to throw up enemys just like Pey'j but he has a field abilty where he will charge head first (helmet equipped of course) to knock down metal barred doors.

What was the final boss like
Obviously with a title like this i shouldn't need to tell you that there will be spoliers but i'll put it here anyway.
SPOLIER ALERT
SPOLIER ALERT
I have warned you. Don't complain if I spoil too much.
The final boss was unique as it had you thinking on your feet as you attack, he steals your uncle which leaves you with yourself and Double H, after killing the clones of your uncle Double H is taken as well and you have to fight the clones of Double H by your self and the clones keep telling you that you should give up, which isn't a option. Adventually you will be weakened as the boss says and will reverse your directional controls regardless of your settings, you can not go into the settings and change them because the game will keep them reversed, im not sure if you can go into the game with reversed directional controls and for it to be flipped. This is unique as i havent seen any other final boss do this. If your a controller user (from the ps2 or xbox 360/PS3 games) you could flip the controller itself making it slightly easier. I will not spoil how the game ends, ill leave that to you

Was there anything i didn't like?
There wasn't much I didn't like. I loved each part of the game. I guess that the most difficult parts would be when you had a drone in the room forceing stealth as it was in a difficult room where the guards are placed in difficult spots to get pass, for example placed at the doorway you need to get out at.

Do I recommend this game
Defently as it will give you hours of fun as the main game lasts for about 7 to 8 hours without getting all the collectables, if your a completionist then it would take about 11 to 14 hours tops to get everything.

This game is absolutely magnificent. It's a puzzle-adventurer, very akin to The Legend of Zelda. A lot of the mechanics revolve around sneaking and not being detected.

There are moments that'll make you cry and leave you on-edge. Jade is a great protagonist, and you'll come to love every character. The graphics are a little dated (the game was originally on PS2, GCN and Xbox, so the resolution is pretty bad and there are quite a few graphical glitches.) I give this game a 9/10 (if it weren't for graphical glitches and sometimes monotonous battle system, it'd definitely get a 10/10)

reviewText:
Short version: 92%Beyond Good & Evil mixes many gameplay elements to create a fun, adventurous, yet surprisingly serious storyline about the struggles of a reporter who slowly uncovers the sinister plot against her home planet. Although it gained some recognition in the past five years, this game is still one of the most underappreciated sparkling gems of this century.

Long version:Beyond Good & Evil was praised by both the press and players alike, yet it is still a perpetual resident on any list that collects the best rarely known games from the past 10-15 years or so.

At first glance, these ratings are difficult to justify ‚Äì after all, the game is a strange hodgepodge of various genres: puzzle, platformer, stealth, 3D brawler, treasure hunt, with some driving and racing on top.
While these mixed-genre games rarely work, somehow the designers managed to keep all of these elements together in a tight knot. After getting used to the controls (a controller helps), we find a game with great mechanics, astonishing levels of large variety, and a small world that constantly offers some activity between the platforming stages, but not in a distracting manner.

The final selling point is the story: we follow the adventures of Jade, a reporter and caretaker of some recently orphaned children. She gradually gets entangled in the war between her home planet and the invading aliens, only to discover the sinister truth behind the attacks, the recent kidnappings, and her own past.
Despite the serious nature of the story, both the aesthetics and the writing tries to be light-hearted and fun, giving a great sense of adventure even when you are discussing battle plans in the back room of a bar. The cast does a wonderful job of delivering some memorable lines, elevating Beyond Good & Evil into a classic status, recommended for anyone who never had the pleasure of playing it.

reviewText:
This was one of my favorite games on the X-box (if not my favorite), and is currently still my top 3 of best games all time. It's just one of those golden oldies where the story, the feel and the gameplay are more important than having the latest shiney graphics (but boring repetative gameplay and zero depth). I bought this to relive the adventure (and to kill time waiting for part 2 ;)), and for the current price on sale I can only recommend everyone to do the same.

You take on the role of reporter Jade and her trusted pig buddy Pey'J, who must fight to uncover a conspiracy of global proportions taking place on their homeplanet Hyllis. The game sports RPG-like elements, since Jade has equipement that can be upgraded by collecting a special currency, blue pearls, which are collected by defeating enemies and minigames. Although the storyline is linear, (parts of) the world can be roamed freely in between missions, giving a great sense of freedom. Most of the characters you encounter while roaming are likeable and often funny. All-in-all the game is strong all-round, offering excelling storytelling and gameplay, and fitting graphics and music.

Why buy it?
Loveable protagonists
Fantastic atmosphere
Great storytelling
Diverse gameplay - fast combat with fun puzzles and minigames
Wonderful music and sound effects
Personally, I also really enjoy the cartoony, colourful graphics style
Why not?
It is a port from the X-box (classic), and a somewhat poor one: some people are having problems setting the game up properly, and are having some difficulties with the controls
It's (13 years!) old, so you might find the graphics a bit outdated

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Beyond Good and Evil is Ubisoft's under-rated-masterpiece, it was first released on the PlayStation 2 on November 11, 2003. The beautiful Music was Composed by Christophe H√©ral.
Beyond Good and Evil is by far the most beautiful, outstanding game I ever played on the PS2, and when I saw it was available on Steam I exploded. There are many games that we as gamers 'play and forget'. Beyond Good and Evil is one of the games I will never forget.


-Video Review!-
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wo3HgK_4kcQ


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: Beyond Good and Evil's Protagonist is a bright young woman named Jade. Jade is an avid martial artist, photographer and investigative reporter. She has been staying with her 'Uncle' Pay'j (A pig/boar-like biped, whom is acting as Jade's Guardian) to help take care of orphans at their lighthouse home.
Jade and Pay'j are on the mining planet ‚ÄúHillys‚Äù. Hillys is under siege by an extraterrestrial group known as the ‚ÄúDomZ‚Äù, the DomZ are skeleton-reaper-like-aliens whom abduct and drain the life from their victims. Recently a group known as ‚ÄúThe Alpha Sections‚Äù have taken up residence on Hillys. The Alpha Sections have sworn to defend the population of Hillys from these devastating DomZ attacks.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511832142

Gameplay: You play the game as Jade, in a third person camera view, the game is broken down into two modes: combat mode and stealth mode. (Side note: There is much more to the game than that, sometimes you need to take pictures, solve puzzles, figure out riddles, play mini games, and have dialogue with other NPC's.)
When in combat, Jade wields a special Bo Staff known as a ‚ÄúJ≈ç‚Äù; Jade preforms strikes, flips, and power attacks while in combat mode. If you were unsuccessful in sneaking past enemies you can fight your way through many parts of the game. However there is definitely an emphasis on stealth rather than fighting.
When in stealth, Jade sneaks and rolls, there are oftentimes alternative paths to sneak around guards, other times you need to distract guards by creating a diversion to take them away from their posts, while you sneak past.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511832150

A final note I should make, is the console to PC port wasn't quite perfect; the camera angle is sometimes a little bit awkward, but you eventually get used to the limitations and controls; Beyond Good and Evil is still very playable.

Achievements: There are no achievements in the game, however there are extra things to collect while playing. You can take pictures of all the animals in the game, and collect all the pearls, and find every M-disks.

Price: Beyond Good and Evil is priced at $9.99, my first play through I unlocked everything before beating the game (I took my sweet time about it, and it took about 9-11 hours) the game can easily take anywhere from 6-8 hours to complete.

When I was younger playing this game on the PS2; I remember that I almost beat this whole game in a day. My parrents left the house in the late morning and I started playing Beyond Good and Evil, when they got back that evening I was still playing. Needless to say, they were not pleased with my binge-playing-habits.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511832156

Conclusion: Seriously, just buy and play this game.

Beyond Good & Evil is a fine game. The story is good, the gameplay is great. It's a free-roam adventure, where you explore a small world and persue the story at your own pace. This game is unpretentiously fun.

I understand that there is a Beyond Good & Evil 2" coming soon; catch up on the storyline first."

BG&E is a game which I could pick up and play to 100% completion any second - and I would enjoy myself. I played it first on my gamecube and when it released on Steam it was an instabuy and an instaplay. Start to finish. And there was hardly any minute, nay second in which I didn't like what the game had to offer.

Before I get to the game itself, just a little insight into my perspective towards a special kind of games (feel free to skip):
This game reminds me of the good ol' Rareware. Back in the 90ies and early 2000's before they sold their soul to Microsoft. Games made with love, attention to detail, heart and (and I can't believe that this is a trademark that needs to be pointed out) color. Games like Banjo-Kazooie, Conkers Bad Fur Day and weirdly enough this Ubisoft-Game stick out to me not just gameplay-wise, but also visually. They are bright where they need to be and dark when it is necessary - but they always ooze charme and liveliness. And to be fair - in its catalog of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and unpolished games, Ubisoft does have some amazing titles - Child of Light and Rayman come to mind. All these aforementioned games fall into a special kind of category for me. They all feel different and distinct from each other, but still weirdly similar. They all share the high quality anyways. But hey, maybe that is just me.

About BG&E itself:
Beyond good and evil is an action adventure mix without any outstanding design decisions, but everything that is in the game, is very well implemented, while still being kinda basic. There is a simple combat system, which doesn't reach the levels of a spectacle fighter - reminiscent of Starfox Adventures. There is a stealth system, but it isn't as deep as the likes of Metal Gear, Splinter Cell or Thief. There is some sense of Open-World-Exploration, but please don't expect GTA or Skyrim. There is photography, but (sadly) no Prof. Oak to evaluate your skills regarding capturing Snorlax' butt on polaroid. And there are racing-sequences, which...well they are rather tight actually - I lik'em.

This game gives you a bit of everything in bitesized chunks and delivers a quite well presented story on the side. It is vast, but not intimidating. You can actually complete it 100% without doing a lot of unnecessary walking and searching - yet it feels rewarding. IMHO this is a game that you need to play to experience its appeal firsthand. Don't read about it, don't watch a Let's play - play it. It is really well polished, casts some memorable characters and, apart from the overall length of the game, does not leave much to be desired.

Firstly, I didn't have a chance to play this when it originally came out and I also don't have too much experience with the 3rd person action adventure genre, so this opinion is relatively nostalgia or genre prejudice free.

My issues with the game are mostly related to technical difficulties when attempting to get it up an running:

It'll always complain that your display drivers are out of date when launching (at least on an ATI card)
Audio goes off sync if you don't run it on a single core affinity
Your display settings need to be correct to avoid texture flickering
No out of box controller support for smoother analogue movement
Probably something a patch or two could fix but they seem to have abandoned this one. You could also work around the controller issue by mapping the buttons using a 3rd party software such as JoyToKey, but you can't make it analogue though. I played this on keyboard and mouse due to that limitation and it's not bad, I just would've liked to play on the couch in Big Picture mode.

Apart from those technical issues I could say that everything else about the game is good. The story and the characters are likeable and well-written. I particularly liked Uncle Pey'j, who is probably now one of my favourite sidekick characters in all games. Voice acting was pretty much spot on for each character, maybe little on a campy side with different accents and all that, but as long as it fits.. Same could be said about the music.

I was a little worried that the early 2000s 3D graphics haven't aged well, but luckily my worries were in vain: Especially character movement and facial animations have stood the test of time and overall the game is still a pleasure to look at.

I wasn't really a fan of the face to face combat sequences, which occasionally just turned into mashing fests with little to no idea which enemy I was targeting. Your character, Jade, also locks into enemies which can make her a bit hard to control in combat. Stealth sections were a nice change of pace though, and I didn't have too much trouble with the camera that seems to have been an issue for others.

Solid fun for 10+ hours. I'm joining the group of people waiting for the sequel.

Meet Jade. She's a brunette beauty with an eye for mystery and a camera to uncover it. When the would-be heroine's futuristic planet is threatened by aliens, Jade finds herself thrust into the heart of a vicious conspiracy that could stretch to the very top of her government. This stylized, extremely gorgeous third-person action-adventure plays very much like a Zelda game.

Jade can explore a huge, water-covered world by hovercraft or take to a variety of islands and interact with merchants, or tackle assignments to earn money and advance the surprisingly deep and intriguing storyline that surrounds her quest. She can also gain a number of items and weapons that are integral to advancing and a lot of fun to wield. Packed full of twists and turns and even a talking man-pig, Ubisoft has crafted yet another big adventure series.
Bright, colorful cartoon characters fight against the evil fascist dark-toned government! It is very charming and sinister, like an actual fascist government trying to HIDE THE SINS OF THEIR DEEDS.

In short: It's cheap!  Buy it!

Then one day in college, I picked it up over a weekend, deciding to play for the heck of it and to finish it once and for all.

Am I glad I did.

The game immerses you in the story from the get-go, forgoing the typical long, drawn-out backstory. The characters are warm and engaging, and all of them, major and minor, are full of depth and life. This is the only game that can honestly make me say I was sad to leave the world when I completed it, and it is the only game I can pick up once every few months and play again, even though I already know the answers to all of the puzzles and where to find all of the hidden items. So imagine my heartbreak when my PS2 copy started to glitch each time I started a new file, and my joy finding that it is available on Steam for only ten dollars!

This game was well-thought out and developed, and I can say without a doubt that it is my favorite game. I am proud to own both the original PS2 copy and now to own it on Steam.

reviewText: Beyond Good and Evil was the first game that I played. I got a second hand PS2 for my birthday, and my parents let me choose one game with it. I was totally new to video games and I had no idea which game I should choose, so I just let the store owner recommend me a game. And so Beyond Good and Evil it was. Luckily the game was in Dutch (my native language). I was around 10 years old back then, and I couldn't understand English. I started playing the game, not knowing what to expect at all. I remember that the game made a lot of impact on me. Of course, this could be because of the fact that this was my first game ever, but eight years later I can tell you that it wasn't just because of that. It was because of the astonishing music, the amazing atmosphere, and the feeling I got when I figured out how to complete a part of the game all by myself, after looking for a walkthrough on the internet. So now it's eight years later, I've probably completed over a hundred other games, great ones too, but Beyond Good and Evil always had a special place in my heart. I've replayed this game over 20 times, and a couple of days ago I bought the PC version too. Beyond Good and Evil will always be one of my most favourite games, and I can highly recommend this game to everyone.

reviewText:
First of all, the PC port is not great. You need to fiddle with the game quite a bit just to run it on a modern PC. Cutscene sound is badly out of sync and I've only managed to partially reduce the issue by limiting the game to one CPU core and running external applications to launch the game. You will also need to disable HW Vertex Processing in advanced graphics options to get rid of the flicker. It also seems that gamepads are not supported, but the M&K layout works just fine, though it's not entirely intuitive.

The game itself feels very dates and doesn't seem to have aged well. The plot is ok, but not very fleshed out. A classic story of a protagonist with exceptional powers, the nature of which is only slightly hinted at at the end of the game itself. The world doesn't feel real.

The controls are clunky, Combat mechanics are pretty bad. It's mostly a game about sneaking with combat being an annoying afterthought, until you get to fight the final boss.

On the bright side, the checkpoints are reliably placed all over the place and you never have to backtrace to much.

As a whole, I would recommend to watch the plot summary on YouTube and play something much more mechanically enjoyable.

reviewText:
Beyond Good and Evil is a 2003 Stealth Action-Adventure game developed by Ubisoft Montpellier, the studio behind the Rayman series and also responsible for original titles like From Dust. Montpellier, as a creative powerhouse, delivered Beyond Good and Evil to critical acclaim, but devastatingly poor sales have infamously seen the sequel perpetually delayed.

This is a horrible port, and you should not buy it.

Beyond Good and Evil is not a perfect game. This is the only version of it I've played, so my experience is not all encompassing. However, I felt that most, if not all, of the problem with the game stemmed from what a horrendous port this is.

It controls absolutely awful, because for a game that is designed solely for gamepads, it dictates that you use the keyboard and mouse. Trying to steer Jade while clicking away in haphazard combos isn't fun at all, along with common mishaps like sticking to walls and desperately waggling the mouse in radial-based menus like an idiot.

There is no gamepad support for this game whatsoever, outside of using a clunky 3rd-party program like Xpadder. So that means when the game restricts you camera to a 2D plane, you just have to deal with it. When it decides to wrench your camera away for you for no apparent reason, you just have to deal with it. When you're desperately wrenching the mouse while janking the hovercraft with the WASD keys to get it around corners, you just have to deal with it.

Those are just the control issues. Even after disabling a certain amount of options to get the game running at above a powerpoint rate (note: simply lowering the settings made the game perform even worse) I had constant plummets in framerate and constant graphical glitches. This port (not by Montpellier) makes Ubisoft's recent debacles look good.

It is, however, a decent game. The gameplay is shallow, and the amount of distractions in the disappointingly small hub-world one-note, but the game is carried by the amazing art style and music. The art style speaks for itself, and the music is worth tracking down if you can. While not sold on the game's cult classic status, the game is a solid casual Action Adventure that doesn't demand much in the way of attention and delivers on the premise plenty.

I'm not recommending this, not because you shouldn't play this, but because you shouldn't play this version. Play the HD version, emulate a console version, by Jove even dig out a sixth gen system and track down a physical copy if you're truly dedicated to playing this game and seeing what the hype is all about.

Playing the Steam version of Beyond Good and Evil will only sour you on an already hard to sell game.

This game is often mentioned as something special, and maybe it is, but ubisoft wont make it easy for you or me to find out.

It seems they've put this game on steam 'as-is', one would assume as a cash grab. They have not updated it for modern HW at all! If your GFX card is younger than 10 years, or you have more than one cpu core (including HT) expect lots of problems; such as slowdowns, texture glitches, and the sound being out of sync with the action/video.

There are lots of posts about this easily found with google. Two solutions often come up that help a little: 1) set CPU affinity to just one CPU core (done with taskman), 2) Set GFX features to manual and turn most things off (google for specifics). oh and you will never be able to get rid of the warning about your GFX drivers being too old.

Steam does not know how many hours I've played because I start the game outside of steam with a .bat script, that tries to adjust some things for the game. I am some hours in and I can appreciate the charm that this games had and I can see why it's so beloved.

Unfortunately unless I can get it to play smothly (i.e. Ubisoft fixes the game), I am not sure I will ever love it.

If you want to play it, I'd suggest finding a 10 year old laptop with winxp to play it on. A real shame...

reviewText: Great atmosphere, once you get past the somewhat lacking controls and perhaps some graphical issues, I must say I got hooked for hours. It's a great mix of point and click adventuring, some platforming and mostly basic fighting (so far) like stuff seen in jack and daxter, or zeldaish with a lock on system.\n\nBut my main reason why I'd recommend this to anyone is the music, and the characters. I've wanted to play this game for a long time and this was the first time I've actually played through it. I really enjoyed it. The story, music, and world were a joy to experience and it's nice to play a game with the early aughts levity that you so seldom get in current games.

Now, would I recommend this for the PC? ....Not necessarily, it is horribly ported. Every time I launched the game it said my graphics card drivers were out of date (they weren't) Apparently, if you run this on a newer machine, the game can't recognize your graphics card and will just pop that error up every time you launch. You can click through it to boot the game up, though. Before you do that, I would suggest going into the advanced settings (not ingame), going into the manual compatibility settings and disabling HW Vertex Processing: it's job is to bug your game out with random polygons and artifacts that make the game unplayable. From what I've read, this happens to a lot of people.

Another problem with the port, this game was designed for a controller, yet there's no controller support. If you're like me, you're going to need to faff about extensively with the control settings to get the game marginally comfortable to play. One thing that I couldn't fix was how both the mouse and WSAD keys sent the same commands when you're in a vehicle and it screws with the camera. All in all, while I got through the game fine enough, it felt like I was limping the whole way because of the poor controls.

The game itself, though, was wonderful. As I took in the music, characters, and setting of the game I was sad that this never got the trilogy it promised to be. It's got a little of everything in it, stealth, action, vehicles, mini-games, puzzles, NPC interaction; its really remarkable that all of this was in it way back in the early 2000's and I felt the experience actually aged quite well. The lightly cartoony look did the game well and avoided the super realistic" games pitfal of looking and playing like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• now. It probably won't happen

Beyond Good and Evil is a fabulous work of art that originally was released for the PS2, GC, Xbox, and those early 2000's pcs.  The game's story is amazing backed up by emotional moments, compeiling characters, and the need to find out just who is really orchestrating the DomZ attacks and who is kidnapping the citizens of Hillys.  Furthermore is the graphics, I don't tend to focus on graphics much, but, Beyond Good and Evil deserves for its graphics to be praised for a world that draws you into it beauty and to this day has aged quite well.  And the music fits every mood rather it be a tough boss battle or sad cutscene.  Gameplay is also solid--Jade's movements in battle always feel smooth and well executed.  Perhaps the most interesting thing I thought about the gameplay was how it combined not just the action adventure of a Zelda game, but the stealth you would find in such as Metal Gear.  Now there are some issues with this game I should address but shouldn't stop you from playing the game.  One, is that the game has not been optimized for modern day pcs, in fact as soon as you start the game you are given an error that your 'Graphics Card' has not been updated to the latest version, but at least you can still play it.  Then theres problems with sometimes flickering graphics and such, and one of the worst that ruined a very important scene in the game near the end was at the middle of the cutscene the sound absolutely stopped (I had to reload an earlier save, turn on subtitles and go through it again just to hear them).  In other words this game is a straight out port of the pc version that has not been optimized for modern day pcs.  But even though it has issues with modern day pcs I found that it was still enjoyable as it was back when it was released.  I suggest Ubisoft releases a patch so that Beyond Good and Evil can run on modern day pcs better, much better.  If you can deal with the issues then you will certainly have a blast playing this overlooked great game.  However if you don't want to deal with the issues then I suggest you buy the HD version on Xbox 360 or PS3.\n

Beyond Good and Evil is a fabulous work of art that originally was released for the PS2, GC, Xbox, and those early 2000's pcs.  The game's story is amazing backed up by emotional moments, compeiling characters, and the need to find out just who is really orchestrating the DomZ attacks and who is kidnapping the citizens of Hillys.  Furthermore is the graphics, I don't tend to focus on graphics much, but, Beyond Good and Evil deserves for its graphics to be praised for a world that draws you into it beauty and to this day has aged quite well.  And the music fits every mood rather it be a tough boss battle or sad cutscene.  Gameplay is also solid--Jade's movements in battle always feel smooth and well executed.  Perhaps the most interesting thing I thought about the gameplay was how it combined not just the action adventure of a Zelda game, but the stealth you would find in such as Metal Gear.  Now there are some issues with this game I should address but shouldn't stop you from playing the game.  One, is that the game has not been optimized for modern day pcs, in fact as soon as you start the game you are given an error that your 'Graphics Card' has not been updated to the latest version, but at least you can still play it.  Then theres problems with sometimes flickering graphics and such, and one of the worst that ruined a very important scene in the game near the end was at the middle of the cutscene the sound absolutely stopped (I had to reload an earlier save, turn on subtitles and go through it again just to hear them).  In other words this game is a straight out port of the pc version that has not been optimized for modern day pcs.  But even though it has issues with modern day pcs I found that it was still enjoyable as it was back when it was released.  I suggest Ubisoft releases a patch so that Beyond Good and Evil can run on modern day pcs better, much better.  If you can deal with the issues then you will certainly have a blast playing this overlooked great game.  However if you don't want to deal with the issues then I suggest you buy the HD version on Xbox 360 or PS3.\n

One of the few Ubisoft games unmarred by hasty, unnecessary sequels, and yet Beyond Good and Evil 2 is a project held in the same respects as Half-Life 3. Though arguably not as purely entertaining as that more popular predecessor, Beyond Good and Evil is a gem.
Rather than one gameplay mechanic that develops through the game, Beyond has several that stay within their simple controls for the game's entirety (pod racing, stealth, style-over-substance combat, etc). In spite of this party-box mentality, none of these segments feel dated or become tired, and serve up some genuine challenge and suspense as the game develops. The story is similarly easy-going, but is carried by memorably colourful characters, making the game's rare darker moments all the more affecting.
Of course, it does have the hallmarks/clich√©s (depending on who you ask) of a PS2 game, and the city hub loses some of the life it once had with the passing years. Non-interactive characters in games have always been an awkward stumbling block (the ever-repeating lines, the passive stares, their jarring inferior animation), and Beyond is a case in point. A last-act collect-a-thon entry requirement that prevents you from reaching the climax is an eye-rolling sign of age, and the fact that it appears after what's easily the game's most powerful moment makes it's appearance all the more unwelcome. Actually carrying out this task, however, is an enjoyable showcase for the game's mechanical variety, and the open-world's now-quaint size is packed with interesting sights and exciting gameplay, which is always more important than sheer mileage.
I'm not yet ready to load my belongings onto the Bring BGAE 2" bandwagon just yet
date: but this is an excellent opener to an unfinished trilogy
